title: A Roadmap to a New Biennial of Design: 3, 2, 1 ... Test

author: Jan Boelen, Z33 House for Contemporary Art

segmentation: There's still a big discussion going on in the knowing food group, how what we will eat tonight, so.
I hope it will be tonight that we eat something.
There were some two questions that are really quite important is some people asked us or ask me why I am selected and how I am selected and in fact it's the answer is very simple.
It's the quality of your work.
It is the basis and we did that separately from the mentors.
Really silly.
And then we put everything together and we we saw that there was a kind of understanding what.
What that quality was.
And of course, that motivation played an important role, and your affinity with the subject and the different roles you maybe could play in the different groups.
So that about the selection.
Another very important question is was and that's the last question that I will answer is where will the party be?
The party will be here in this space.
So.
To make that clear tonight the party will be here.
Um?

Another thing is that this afternoon is like very short and we try to make it short because these are every time you are in conference is the most boring and long moments after dinner and after lunch everybody falls asleep.
So I will try to jump through a kind of ID, why, why we're doing?
What we are doing.
Why we picked the ID's.
The other teams maybe why we picked the teams as they are formulated now.
How they maybe can change through your discussions and finally we give you an insight to survive Bill.
You already may be found somewhere a Survival kit.
You will get a Survival kit and it will be done by Maya.
And I don't see her.
She disappears, she yeah.

And then we go on how we will communicate with each other and in several ways, and how we will not only internally will try to communicate, but also try to communicate with the outside world to be also transparent and to share our process is.
And the next step is that we are going to introduce the mentors.
So I asked the certain time all the mentors here in.
And on the stage which is not here, it's really that stage, but at least in front here.
To to say something very particular just on on an object or a project they did I do that together with my offer done who helps me to Co, curate, curate this biennial so.
I addressed already a topic, why do we still need to buy annuals of design and why do we need them here in Slovenia?
If you know that in.
Autumn 2014.
They are from London.
Paris ain't often cortech Brussels and you go down to Europe and you finally end in that Autumn 2014.
You're entering Istanbul and probably other places of this world and everywhere you see design events popping up that are not only by annuals, they are like try annuals.
You have events months of design.
And so on.
You have weeks and everywhere designers puts on a certain stage.
Most of the time you can see this is same things everywhere.
There are the same objects that you maybe already saw earlier, and even for 80% you see them.
So I don't go anymore.
I find them boring.
I don't find them interesting and there are time consuming and they're like these big parties.
Ice, it's already several times in the day after you have a hangover.
And then 9064 here somebody had the ID.
I still don't know who, but somebody gotta ID to set up a design biennial.
The first one in the world, it's the oldest one.
9064 an it came out of a need and I think you always if you do something you have to formulate in need.
Otherwise you better can stop.
And I thought maybe when they ask me maybe they better stop.
Despite no, because it's not making sense anymore.
Where is the need to do something so that was in 1964 there was a need to bring together in this country.
At that moment, Yougoslavia to bring together the eastern and Western world.
Kind of local international meeting point.
Very interesting thought.
And to do that byproducts and IDs and by all kind of.
Um?
Events around it and it made sense to me at that time.
Use also in the introduction this morning from SVEDKA.
The rich dumb of this history and I find also I find that very interesting.
So it's not only that the past is bad, but it's also can be very inspiring and very enriching.
And where we do too now today 2014 the world changed.
As we know, Yougoslavia is not there anymore.
We don't can bring it back so we have to look maybe forward Europe changed.
2014 The economic economical situation is changing.
How are we responding to that new reality?
And how can biannual play a role in that kind of world?
And when I start talking and meeting people here, I was looking for that neat and.
Such a mistake was in his ear.
Came up with the ID which he already got so long time.
How can a country which and I interrupted him?
How can a country which is in Europe infected city because it's only 2 million people.
How can a country be laboratory for design and because it has an interesting scale like 2 million people.
You have a coast you have helps.
You have all kinds of environments.
You have just the scale a critical mass.
To do something with you can call people and two hours or three hours later or the day after you can meet and you can start doing things so it is also from perspective of scale.
It could work and you have different contexts and it is a crossing point which is also very interesting.
So how could Slovenia act as a laboratory for design?
And how would build looked in that biannual of design in 2014?
And when I was talking with a lot of people, I heard that they wanted to connect.
They wanted to link, they wanted to collaborate and there was a kind of conflict in the model that was presented earlier on in that local international design competition.
What it was and I thought, yeah, this is not really helping what we need or what we want.
Maybe it's better to think about a local international design collaboration, really bringing people together and start working, but yeah.

I know also that if we collaborate, I not just want to do that for the sake of collaboration, I want to talk about something I want to talk about, meaningful things that are related to everyday life, and in fact, because I don't think design in itself is interesting, it is not about the world of design, and that's maybe why, designed by animals are to me boring because they are self preferential, they are.
Like dare to embrace an praise, the role of the designer.
Of course, that is important, but it's not about that world of design, it is.
About designing the world and maybe not the world itself, because that is quite large and ambitious.
Maybe it's just about life and that is.
I thought this is maybe an interesting shift.
So if you talk and you start doing things.
What are the main themes of everyday life?
If you would collaborate, what are the teams of everyday life?
What is it?
And.
It's not here, but the first one of the first days I met Marco Peterlin and he was I just asked and it was kind of intuitive thing.
What?
What is your dream?
What?
What would you like to do in not just in your, in your profession but also in your life?
And he said, I want to do a project about walking.
Just walking wow.
I thought this is great.
How can walking what we do every day?
How can that become meaningful?
How can walking be something that we never thought of and how that it can become important and it is debt.
These kind of meetings and dreams that I found because I really found him and didn't look for them particularly.
I didn't search for them.
They were there.
Look he is running a little Institute epap and their teams they are researching are related to that, but it's not completely one to one.

It is a kind of field of interest and that field of interest can be matched with what can happen in beer and we can bring together his knowledge together with knowledge that is around and that is something I wanted to do because then we know about what we are talking and if you know about what we are talking.
We can start developing a project, found that on several levels on public water I met also another Marco.
And he is an engineer, and normally I have to admit and I don't.
I don't hope there is here an engineer with the X, but.
We designers don't like too much engineers.
Most of the time they are very rational, but he was talking about how that water could play a role in everyday life.
How did he is running through the city and how that he is running through the city and drink, stopping at certain places he don't take a bottle of water with him.
It doesn't take a plastic bottle with him, but he runs to the places where you can drink water in public space and he was fascinated.
Instead of trying to get rid of rainwater.
As fast as possible.
It may be also could play a role in public space.
How could that create an environment where you can play with water?
How it can change a square?
And I thought yes, this is also interesting.
This goes beyond what we expect and this goes beyond.
And how can we connect it?
Because he has a lot of technological.
And now how with poetry, how can we connect it with all kind of elements that?
Make things more meaningful.
So you see all these.
Seems you know them you applied for them and we.
Will start working on them.
I hope that we will think beyond product of course products and objects will play a role, but it's for me really.
A testing ground laboratory.
I want to present it also as a laboratory.
So in the exhibition itself I would like to see things with the visual quality that appeal to people that inspire people and that will hopefully get an afterlife.
Have look.
Pick two this morning that the things that we do that they at least, if they are put in the exhibition that they inspire us to go on after Bill with it so that there is.
They are things of becoming instead of things that are there like they are.
They are not the truth, they are a truth.
So there are.
Formulating a possible future.
An I hope that Bill 50 will become debt so that we are not only looking back to the past, but that we are also looking forward.
Anne.

And you ask, I already went a little bit further, but what do we expect is in fact I like to see at the end these objects that have a certain visual quality, that there may be a scenario, maybe a process, maybe a poem, but that can be presented in space in an exhibition.
And that is.
In hope in order to inspire people, how do we work?
I don't know it.
I really don't know.
And I don't have one answer.
Every group is another constellation of different people of different roles.
So what we will do is we will try.
The coming day to inspire you.
Sometimes you go to some places you go to a neighborhood and so on, and you have to re question the brief.
The first brief that we gave to you.
You have to re question that together with the group.
We hope that out of debt.
Redefining the open assignment.
You come in the group to assert certain.
Common grounds, and by doing that I hope that you can make a working plan that to tomorrow evening before you leave that everybody knows we are working on a project like this.
This is my role and this is the time schedule and this is how we will communicate in the group and every group has to formulate that themselves.
That means that some groups maybe will meet every day.
By Skype or Facebook or meet physically here or some people do that, or they just say we come one time we come together or two times and finally there is 1 the week before the opening.
That is the main deadline.
There we want to see that visual representation of what you did.
So I hope these are more or less questions.
Answers on your questions.
It's a risky thing which we are doing, but I also.
Think failure is interesting just like Lisbeth was mentioning, or Thomas was mentioning.
Failure is also something we can communicate with the public, but it matters how that we do it, how we will stage the failure.
That's also why the title is there.
321 test.
It's really a testing ground in the laboratory.
Sometimes things fail and the failures are can be interesting, but it's the way we handled the failures and what and if we see.
The importance in the failures.
In fact, I hope we don't have failures, but we go on and that we have kind of inspiration for the future.
So there I explained the title, explained a little bit to 50 years.
And I hope that design will connect everything again with everyday life.
Thank you very much and hope that it will work.
